posts.raw_content:
Once they determined he had Covid they started him on Remdesevir right away. I know that we determined Remdesevir is ineffective at best, and deadly at worst. Are there any links to support this? How did we come to this conclusion?

Edit: This is the disclaimer docs have to sign for using Remdesivir. I found it in the medical records:

Order: Remdesivir Attestation
Order Comment: I attest that the patient is currently hospitalized and clinical status warrants continued hospitalization. The
patient has a laboratory confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection or a strong suspicion for current COVID-19 disease (if stat in-house
testing was unavailable). The patient does not have a history of hypersensitivity reaction to any ingredient of remdesivir and
currently has symptoms of COVID-19 disease including oxygenation status of: · Documented SpO2 of above 94% on room air
and prescriber has documented that patient has CDC-defined risk factors for progression to severe illness and, in their clinical
judgment, potential benefits outweigh potential risks, or · Documented SpO2 of 94% or less on room air, or · Requiring
supplemental oxygen I attest that the patient’s hepatic function was assessed. ALTs have been done within the last 24 hours
and were either normal or, if ALTs were elevated, there were no signs of hepatic inflammation and the benefit of remdesivir
outweighs the risk of potentially worsening ALT. I attest that prothrombin time assessment was performed. The prothrombin
time was done within the last 24 hours and is within normal range or, if outside of normal range, the benefit of remdesivir
outweighs the risks of potentially increasing the prothrombin time. A pregnancy assessment has been completed as
applicable for women of childbearing age. If used during pregnancy, the potential benefit of remdesivir outweighs the potential
risk to the mother and the fetus. For breastfeeding mothers, an assessment of risk to the infant has been completed and the
potential benefit of remdesivir outweighs the potential risk to the infant. A drug-drug interaction screening has identified no
drug-drug interactions or, in the event that a drug-drug interaction was identified, the potential benefit of remdesivir outweighs
potential risks of drug-drug interaction. I attest that, as the healthcare practitioner treating this patient diagnosed with
COVID-19, I have obtained consent from the patient or patient’s legal representative prior to prescribing treatment. In
obtaining consent, I have provided an explanation of alternative medications for the treatment of COVID-19 and the relative
advantages, disadvantages, and risks associated with such alternative medications, to the extent necessary to allow the
patient or patient’s legal guardian to make a prudent treatment decision. When determining alternative medications to present
to the patient, I have included information on any medications currently authorized or approved by the U.S. FDA for treatment
of COVID-19. I have used my best clinical judgment to identify any alternative medications that could reasonably be expected
to benefit the patient. In making my decisions, I have considered the physical state of the patient and the patient’s ability to
understand the information.
posts.author: StormyDaniels
posts.title: Friends’ healthy dad was killed in the hospital. They gave him Remdesivir right away.
posts.content:
Once they determined he had Covid they started him on Remdesevir right away. I know that we determined Remdesevir is ineffective at best, and deadly at worst. Are there any links to support this? How did we come to this conclusion?

Edit: This is the disclaimer docs have to sign for using Remdesivir. I found it in the medical records:

Order: Remdesivir Attestation Order Comment: I attest that the patient is currently hospitalized and clinical status warrants continued hospitalization. The patient has a laboratory confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection or a strong suspicion for current COVID-19 disease (if stat in-house testing was unavailable). The patient does not have a history of hypersensitivity reaction to any ingredient of remdesivir and currently has symptoms of COVID-19 disease including oxygenation status of: · Documented SpO2 of above 94% on room air and prescriber has documented that patient has CDC-defined risk factors for progression to severe illness and, in their clinical judgment, potential benefits outweigh potential risks, or · Documented SpO2 of 94% or less on room air, or · Requiring supplemental oxygen I attest that the patient’s hepatic function was assessed. ALTs have been done within the last 24 hours and were either normal or, if ALTs were elevated, there were no signs of hepatic inflammation and the benefit of remdesivir outweighs the risk of potentially worsening ALT. I attest that prothrombin time assessment was performed. The prothrombin time was done within the last 24 hours and is within normal range or, if outside of normal range, the benefit of remdesivir outweighs the risks of potentially increasing the prothrombin time. A pregnancy assessment has been completed as applicable for women of childbearing age. If used during pregnancy, the potential benefit of remdesivir outweighs the potential risk to the mother and the fetus. For breastfeeding mothers, an assessment of risk to the infant has been completed and the potential benefit of remdesivir outweighs the potential risk to the infant. A drug-drug interaction screening has identified no drug-drug interactions or, in the event that a drug-drug interaction was identified, the potential benefit of remdesivir outweighs potential risks of drug-drug interaction. I attest that, as the healthcare practitioner treating this patient diagnosed with COVID-19, I have obtained consent from the patient or patient’s legal representative prior to prescribing treatment. In obtaining consent, I have provided an explanation of alternative medications for the treatment of COVID-19 and the relative advantages, disadvantages, and risks associated with such alternative medications, to the extent necessary to allow the patient or patient’s legal guardian to make a prudent treatment decision. When determining alternative medications to present to the patient, I have included information on any medications currently authorized or approved by the U.S. FDA for treatment of COVID-19. I have used my best clinical judgment to identify any alternative medications that could reasonably be expected to benefit the patient. In making my decisions, I have considered the physical state of the patient and the patient’s ability to understand the information.
